Catalog_Raisonne: Murase, Art through a Lifetime, no. 165
creditline: Mary Griggs Burke Collection, Gift of the Mary and Jackson Burke Foundation
medium: Six-panel folding screen, one of a pair, ink and color on gold
object_name: folding screen, six-panel, one of a pair
text: Red-crowned cranes were once ubiquitous throughout the wetlands of China, Korea, and Japan. Their impressive size (up to five feet tall), striking coloration, and lively “dance” made them a popular subject among artists. In East Asian mythology, they were believed to live for a thousand years, and thus became auspicious symbols of longevity. This set of screens would have been appropriate for especially felicitous events such as birthday and New Year’s celebrations.
title: Cranes [right of a pair]
